headline: X Gets a Brazilian Ax + Founder Mode + Listeners Respond on School Phone Bans
snippet: “This is not a normal legal dispute.”
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, X was banned in Brazil. We talk with The New York Times’s Brazil bureau chief, Jack Nicas, about how Brazilians are reacting, whether its owner, Elon Musk, has made a business miscalculation and what this means for free speech around the world. Then, we’re going “founder mode.” We explore why an essay about start-up founders reclaiming their authority went viral and what that tells us about how Silicon Valley thinks about power. And finally, we hear from listeners. Teachers and students left us voice messages describing how phone bans in schools are transforming their lives.

headline: Starliner’s Troubles Are Latest Setback for Boeing’s Space Business
snippet: The capsule, which returned without astronauts, and other space programs at Boeing have suffered many delays and cost overruns.
lead_paragraph: Space programs are a small part of Boeing’s business, which is dominated by sales of commercial and military planes and equipment. But the work is a point of pride: Boeing has long been involved in spaceflight, going back to the first mission to take an American to space.

headline: How Elon Musk Is Influencing Donald Trump
snippet: Their fast-evolving political friendship has become a potential minefield, as Mr. Musk’s sprawling businesses may present conflicts of interest if Mr. Trump is elected in November.
lead_paragraph: In a live-streamed conversation on X with former President Donald J. Trump last month, Elon Musk raised the idea of a “government efficiency commission.” Such a council could ensure that taxpayers’ money was “spent in a good way,” Mr. Musk said during their more-than-two-hour talk.

headline: Trump Media Shares Are Down 74% From Their March Peak
snippet: The stock price of the former president’s social media company has often moved in tandem with investor perception of his standing in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company have fallen so much that his onetime $6 billion stake is now worth about $2 billion.

headline: Are People Named Dennis Really More Likely to Become Dentists?
snippet: The weird, mostly bad science of nominative determinism.
lead_paragraph: Long before Reddit users discovered the firefighter Les McBurney, humans were fascinated by the idea that a person’s name influences his destiny.

headline: TikTok Expands Its ‘How to Vote’ Resources Ahead of the Election
snippet: The company is an increasingly popular source of political news. It’s adding more content about how elections work and media literacy.
lead_paragraph: TikTok is pushing to improve information about the upcoming U.S. presidential election on the app, it said Wednesday.

headline: The Push to Ban Phones in School
snippet: A growing number of states are cracking down on students’ use of the devices.
lead_paragraph: As students around the United States head back to school, many are encountering a new reality: bans on their use of cellphones.

headline: Boeing Starliner Set to Leave Space Station Without Its Crew
snippet: The troubled spacecraft is scheduled to undock on Friday for a trip back to Earth while two NASA astronauts will stay in orbit.
lead_paragraph: Leaving behind the two NASA astronauts it took to the International Space Station three months ago, Boeing’s troubled Starliner spacecraft is set to begin its return to Earth on Friday evening.

headline: Japan Tries to Reclaim Its Clout as a Global Tech Leader
snippet: Japanese chip companies are tapping billions of dollars and collaborating with foreign firms as part of new government policies that look outward.
lead_paragraph: China’s envy-inducing success in using industrial policy to expand its economy and finance green manufacturing has helped kick off a fevered scrimmage among nations to develop and protect their own hometown businesses.

headline: Judge Sets 2025 Timeline for Remedies to Google’s Search Monopoly
snippet: After ruling against Google last month, Judge Amit P. Mehta said he would take until next August to determine fixes that the company must make.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said on Friday that he planned to deliver a punishment for Google’s internet search monopoly by August 2025, kicking off a new phase in an antitrust case that could reshape the tech giant and change competition on the internet.

headline: Telegram’s Founder, in First Comments Since Arrest, Defends the App
snippet: Pavel Durov, held in France since last month, blamed “growing pains” for the company’s problems and pledged to make improvements.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the founder of the online communications tool Telegram, said on Thursday that it was a “misguided approach” to hold him personally responsible for the spread of illicit content on the platform.

headline: Waymo’s Robot Taxis Are Almost Mainstream. Can They Now Turn a Profit?
snippet: Now that its technology is showing it can work on city streets, Alphabet, which owns Waymo, plans to invest billions more.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, Waymo’s robot taxis have become an unmistakable part of the San Francisco experience.

headline: Internet Archive Loses Court Appeal in Fight Over Online Lending Library
snippet: The dispute started in the early days of the pandemic when the organization expanded access to a free online collection of books.
lead_paragraph: When libraries across the country temporarily closed in the early days of the pandemic, the Internet Archive, an organization that digitizes and archives materials like web pages and music, had the idea to make its library of scanned books free to read in an online database.

headline: Start-Up Investors Push Back Against Venture Capital’s Bigger-Is-Better Mantra
snippet: A small but vocal group is forming new funds and taking new approaches to counter the swell of money into venture capital in recent years.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 10 years running his own venture capital firm, Nick Chirls decided to call it quits this year.

headline: How Telegram Became a Playground for Criminals, Extremists and Terrorists
snippet: Drug dealers, scammers and white nationalists openly conduct business and spread toxic speech on the platform, according to a Times analysis of more than 3.2 million Telegram messages.
lead_paragraph: Telegram has become a global sewer of criminal activity, disinformation, child sexual abuse material, terrorism and racist incitement, according to a four-month investigation by The New York Times that analyzed more than 3.2 million Telegram messages from over 16,000 channels. The company, which offers features that enable criminals, terrorists and grifters to organize at scale and to sidestep scrutiny from the authorities, has looked the other way as illegal and extremist activities have flourished openly on the app.

headline: Russia Secretly Worms Its Way Into America’s Conservative Media
snippet: Federal prosecutors say Russia paid an American media company to push pro-Kremlin messages from social media influencers including Benny Johnson, Tim Pool and Dave Rubin.
lead_paragraph: In early 2022, a young couple from Canada, Lauren Chen and Liam Donovan, registered a new company in Tennessee that went on to create a social media outlet called Tenet Media.

headline: OpenAI, Still Haunted by Its Chaotic Past, Is Trying to Grow Up
snippet: The maker of ChatGPT is struggling to transform itself into a profit-driven company while satisfying worries about the safety of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI, the often troubled standard-bearer of the tech industry’s push into artificial intelligence, is making substantial changes to its management team, and even how it is organized, as it courts investments from some of the wealthiest companies in the world.

headline: Will Automation Replace Jobs? Port Workers May Strike Over It.
snippet: A contract covering longshore workers on the East and Gulf Coasts will expire at the end of September, but talks have been stalled over the use of equipment that can function without human operators.
lead_paragraph: When a dockworkers’ union broke off contract talks with management in June, raising the likelihood of a strike at more than a dozen ports on the East and Gulf Coasts that could severely disrupt the supply chain this fall, it was not over wages, pensions or working conditions. It was about a gate through which trucks enter a small port in Mobile, Ala.

headline: Left-Wing Misinformation Is Having a Moment
snippet: America’s right flank remains the chief purveyor of misinformation, but this summer’s political tumult created ideal conditions for falsehoods to spread among progressives.
lead_paragraph: Several elected officials, along with a top political aide for the billionaire Reid Hoffman, recently suggested, without proof, that former President Donald J. Trump may have staged an attempt to assassinate him in July.

headline: Russia Imprisons Top Physicists, Even as Putin Touts Their Technology
snippet: A Moscow court sentenced Alexander Shiplyuk, the director of a physics institute who specializes in hypersonic flight, to 15 years in prison. It was the latest treason case against a leading scientist.
lead_paragraph: Russian scientists helped make their country a leader in developing cutting-edge missiles that fly at least five times as fast as the speed of sound. Then Russia started calling them traitors.

headline: The Battle to Control the World’s Most Powerful Technology
snippet: Nvidia chips, which are crucial to artificial intelligence, are traded actively in China, despite U.S. restrictions, The Times found.
lead_paragraph: The American company Nvidia has created one of the world’s most sought-after inventions: a computer chip that powers artificial intelligence.

headline: Shiny New Technology, Same Old Funny Business
snippet: Antitrust regulators are finally catching up to the methods used by modern corporations to exert their power.
lead_paragraph: Illegal price fixing used to require a lot of work. In the mid-1990s, to fix the price of the animal feed additive lysine, executives of some of the world’s biggest agribusinesses had to spend hours on airplanes flying to resorts where they spent days in conference rooms determining how much lysine each company could sell, and at what price.

headline: A.I. Isn’t Magic, but Can It Be ‘Agentic’?
snippet: So-called agentic artificial intelligence doesn’t require a human to tell it what to do. At least, that’s the idea.
lead_paragraph: Spend enough time talking to tech executives and you might come away thinking generative artificial intelligence — the technology behind ChatGPT and other services that can create text, video and images — is about to upend every aspect of our lives.

headline: Trailblazing Innovation in Cancer Treatment
snippet: In the fight against cancer, life-saving interventions once believed to be only fiction are on a path to becoming fact.

headline: Yuval Noah Harari: What Happens When the Bots Compete for Your Love?
snippet: The world will soon be flooded with fake humans.
lead_paragraph: Democracy is a conversation. Its function and survival depend on the available information technology. For most of history, no technology existed for holding large-scale conversations among millions of people. In the premodern world, democracies existed only in small city-states like Rome and Athens, or in even smaller tribes. Once a polity grew large, the democratic conversation collapsed, and authoritarianism remained the only alternative.

headline: Wall Street Is Unsettled Again, After Fueling a Global Sell-Off
snippet: Another day of anxiety hit stock markets around the world, with technology stocks the focus of attention.
lead_paragraph: Markets remained unsettled on Wednesday as technology stocks continued to fall, dragging down stock indexes across the world for a second consecutive day.

headline: Is Hydrogen the Missing Piece in Solving the World’s Energy Puzzle?
snippet: A unique hydrogen ecosystem strategy is making the prospect of a hydrogen society increasingly feasible.

headline: Brian Ketcham, Effective Foe of Traffic and Smog, Dies at 85
snippet: An engineer and influential environmentalist in New York, he fought for bus lanes, bridge tolls and limits on parking and against more highways, as in the aborted Westway plan.
lead_paragraph: Brian T. Ketcham, an engineer and influential environmentalist who promoted mass transit and favored bridge tolls, bus lanes, limits on parking and other curbs on vehicular traffic in New York City, died on Aug. 21 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: How Self-Driving Cars Get Help From Humans Hundreds of Miles Away
snippet: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.
lead_paragraph: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.

headline: Stocks Slump and Oil Prices Slide as Unease Returns to Markets
snippet: The S&P 500 fell more than 2 percent on Tuesday, its biggest single-day drop since an early August meltdown.
lead_paragraph: A sharp decline in major stock indexes on Tuesday ruptured a weekslong rebound on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 falling by the most in nearly a month.

headline: The Challenge Is to Write 50,000 Words in a Month. Should ChatGPT Be Able to Help?
snippet: An online writing community was set aflame this week after National Novel Writing Month, or NaNoWriMo, said it wouldn’t take a stance on the use of A.I.
lead_paragraph: For over 20 years, writers around the world have participated in National Novel Writing Month, or #NaNoWriMo, as it’s known online. The challenge is simple: Write 50,000 words in the month of November. Well, as simple as writing 50,000 words can be. (That’s 1,667 words per day, for those of you doing the math at home.)

headline: Trump Praises Tariffs, and William McKinley, to Power Brokers
snippet: In an address about the kind of economy he hopes to build for the 21st century, the former president harked back to the end of another century: the 19th.
lead_paragraph: The titans of finance who gathered on Thursday at the Economic Club of New York may have hoped to hear how former President Donald J. Trump would take the nation into the era of artificial intelligence, private space travel and self-driving electric cars.

headline: As Gunfire Rang Out, Students and Teachers Huddled in Fear
snippet: In classrooms, screams and voices urging everyone to stay quiet were heard. Some had to stay put for more than an hour.
lead_paragraph: The lockdown alert flashed on a screen in Stephen Kreyenbuhl’s classroom at Apalachee High School as the gunfire started.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 6, 2024
snippet: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Smartphones in Schools
snippet: How educators are fighting against distractions.
lead_paragraph: Several times a year, I visit a high school or a college to talk with students about how I do my job and how they see the world. On a typical visit, I spend a few minutes in the back of the classroom while the teacher is conducting another part of that day’s lesson. These experiences have shown me what a dominant — and distracting — role smartphones and laptops play in today’s schools.

headline: U.S. Blowback to Steel Merger Vexes Japan
snippet: A looming decision in Washington to block Nippon Steel’s merger with U.S. Steel on national security grounds is raising sharp questions in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: The prospect that President Biden is ready to block a merger between Nippon Steel and U.S. Steel on national security grounds is stirring discontent in Tokyo, where some officials view the action as casting Japan, a key U.S. ally, as a threat.

headline: We Must Invest in Our Aging Nuclear Arsenal
snippet: All three legs of America’s nuclear triad need substantial modernization and billions of dollars to keep pace with our adversaries.
lead_paragraph: After decades of global nuclear arms reductions, every nuclear state run by an authoritarian regime is heavily increasing its weapons and capabilities. The global balance of nuclear power is changing, and the United States and its allies must also change their mind-set and invest in their own nuclear arms and missile defense.

headline: Netflix Adds Disclaimer to Indian Show After Anger Over Hijacker Names
snippet: The series, based on a 1999 plane hijacking, prompted backlash on social media. Critics claimed it wrongly portrayed the Islamist hijackers as Hindus.
lead_paragraph: Netflix expanded a disclaimer for Indian audiences with a fictional series inspired by the 1999 hijacking of a plane by Islamist militants, after social media users and a high-ranking member of India’s ruling party accused it of portraying the hijackers as Hindus.

headline: How Swing State Politics Are Sinking a Global Steel Deal
snippet: As the Biden administration nears a decision to block the proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel, the debate over national and economic security is being dwarfed by presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has spent the past three years promoting a policy of “friend-shoring,” which aims to contain China and Russia by forging closer ties with U.S. allies like Europe and Japan.

headline: South Korean Teenagers Detained Over Deepfake Sexual Images
snippet: The country has been hit by a wave of sexually explicit videos and pictures that have spread online, prompting the authorities to launch a sweeping investigation.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in South Korea are investigating a surge of sexually explicit images and video clips that have spread online and shocked the nation, leading the police to detain seven male suspects — six of them teenagers — the police said on Tuesday.

headline: They Had Thriving Lives on X, Until Brazil Banned It Overnight
snippet: The ban on Elon Musk’s X has dealt a blow to Brazilians whose livelihoods depended on internet followings they had amassed for years, and which disappeared overnight.
lead_paragraph: Just hours before X went dark in Brazil, Adrienni Rodrigues, a music producer, rushed onto the social network to share the biggest news of her career: the launch of her first album.

headline: China Woos Africa, Casting Itself as Global South’s Defender
snippet: More than 50 African leaders have gathered in Beijing for a summit aimed at projecting the influence of China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in the developing world.
lead_paragraph: African flags have been flown over Tiananmen Square. Leaders of African nations have been greeted by dancers, honor guards and children waving flags. They have been escorted in extensive motorcades past banners celebrating “A Shared Future for China and Africa” and giant, elaborate flower arrangements.

headline: I’m Just a Human Sitting in Front of a Stack of Blank Paper, Sketching as Fast as I Can
snippet: My nine months as a generative art model.
lead_paragraph: Last December, I announced the creation of the very first non-artificial-intelligence generative art model.

headline: A Courtship Filled with Dijon Chicken and Love Notes
snippet: Molly Shoemaker and Cody Wymore met at a community theater in 2018. He impressed her by bringing in home-cooked meals.
lead_paragraph: During the 2018 production of “Ragtime” for the AfterWork Theater in Manhattan, Molly Antoinette Shoemaker and Cody James Wymore were determined to keep things professional. She was the show’s director and he, the music director.

headline: To Survive in the Future, Humanity May Need to Become Less Human
snippet: In Hiromi Kawakami’s new science fiction novel, Earth is a place of surveillance, isolation and dread. The characters (and clones) are doing their best to stay alive.
lead_paragraph: People are produced in factories. Communities exist in isolation, spread out from one another by design. Children are raised by groups of mothers, a network of caretakers who may not be altogether human. One narrator seems closer to vegetable than animal. A man can project his mind onto the brain of a bird, but the technology for space travel is long lost. Earth is a place of dread, and humanity might be done for. The problem, summarized by one character: “how to preserve even a slim chance that we might someday thrive on this planet again.”

headline: Night of the Supermodels in New York, Guest Appearance by Rihanna
snippet: What happened when Pieter Mulier brought the Alaïa show to the Guggenheim.
lead_paragraph: It takes a lot to distract from Rihanna. Especially when she enters a room wearing a cleavage-spilling corset underneath a cream net gown with hundreds of seed pearls caught in its web, sits next to Liv Tyler and starts whispering in her ear.

headline: Georgia Shooting Might Have Been ‘Way Worse’ Without Security Steps
snippet: Measures like a new alert system did not prevent a shooting, but did save lives, according to law enforcement officials.
lead_paragraph: The deadliest episode of school violence in Georgia’s history could have ended with even more bloodshed, if not for the school’s newly installed security systems, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: 3 Moody, Terror-Laced New Thrillers
snippet: Our columnist on new books from T.J. Newman, Andrea Mara and A.E. Gauntlett.
lead_paragraph: Nobody wants to think there might be SOMEONE IN THE ATTIC (Pamela Dorman Books, 355 pp., $29). Andrea Mara’s latest book opens in Dublin as a woman named Anya finishes a bottle of wine, settles into her bath and hears an ominous rustling overhead. She doesn’t stand a chance. “Thirty seconds later, it’s over,” Mara writes.

headline: Review: This ‘Figaro’ Puts All Mozart’s Characters in One Voice
snippet: By singing men and women, nobles and servants, the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo takes the opera’s theme of human mutability to a chaotic extreme.
lead_paragraph: Charles Dickens was celebrated for solo public readings in which he would give voice to a novel’s full cast of characters. I’ve watched the great actor David Greenspan take all the roles in Eugene O’Neill’s sprawling play “Strange Interlude” and, earlier this year, saw Eddie Izzard do the same in “Hamlet.”
